titleNullable: Motion Labs - Machine Generated Power Logging
subtitleNullable: Motion Labs PM-XXX Series Power Meter, lets explore how clients use event power
descriptionNullable:
I originally started a project while working with this data for an in-house AV company, as a Power Distribution Technician, in my spare time. It was only a basic script that plotted 3 graphs, made some HTML files with plotly and had to be run from the console.

This is Machine Generated Power usage data from a Motion Labs PM-XXX Series Power Meter that generates a CSV file on a USB stick, one log file per day, logs every 23 seconds or so.  

Logged parameters are as follows (copied from the User Manual):

- Date (file name) and time (Record Time)
- Ph-N voltages: V1-V2-V3 (single phase, 120 V)
- Ph-Ph voltages: U12-U23-U31 (two phase 208 V)
- Phase currents: I1-I2-I3 
- Frequency
- Average Ph-N voltage: Va
- Average Ph-Ph voltage: Ua
- Average current: Ia
- Total active power (kW)
- Total reactive power (kVAr)
- Total apparent power (kVA)
- Total power factor (pf)
- Demands: dI1-dI2-dI3-dIn-dkW-dkVAr
- Total harmonic distortion: V1-V2-V3-U12-U23-U31-I1-I2-I3-In

more details can be found in the [User Manual](https://www.motionlabs.com/wp-content/uploads/PM-XXX-Manual.pdf) and [Product page](https://www.motionlabs.com/products/modular-power-distribution-3/).  

As you will see, the file i edited will display all the columns, but the ones I didn't edit will only show 2 columns.  that is how Kaggle handled the input; no problem, I will use pandas to work with the data and clean it up so it will be usable.  for analysis, plotting and storytelling.
title: Motion Labs - Machine Generated Power Logging
subtitle: Motion Labs PM-XXX Series Power Meter, lets explore how clients use event power
description:
I originally started a project while working with this data for an in-house AV company, as a Power Distribution Technician, in my spare time. It was only a basic script that plotted 3 graphs, made some HTML files with plotly and had to be run from the console.

This is Machine Generated Power usage data from a Motion Labs PM-XXX Series Power Meter that generates a CSV file on a USB stick, one log file per day, logs every 23 seconds or so.  

Logged parameters are as follows (copied from the User Manual):

- Date (file name) and time (Record Time)
- Ph-N voltages: V1-V2-V3 (single phase, 120 V)
- Ph-Ph voltages: U12-U23-U31 (two phase 208 V)
- Phase currents: I1-I2-I3 
- Frequency
- Average Ph-N voltage: Va
- Average Ph-Ph voltage: Ua
- Average current: Ia
- Total active power (kW)
- Total reactive power (kVAr)
- Total apparent power (kVA)
- Total power factor (pf)
- Demands: dI1-dI2-dI3-dIn-dkW-dkVAr
- Total harmonic distortion: V1-V2-V3-U12-U23-U31-I1-I2-I3-In

more details can be found in the [User Manual](https://www.motionlabs.com/wp-content/uploads/PM-XXX-Manual.pdf) and [Product page](https://www.motionlabs.com/products/modular-power-distribution-3/).  

As you will see, the file i edited will display all the columns, but the ones I didn't edit will only show 2 columns.  that is how Kaggle handled the input; no problem, I will use pandas to work with the data and clean it up so it will be usable.  for analysis, plotting and storytelling.
